text: Product leadership is the type of role where if you are not in control of the voices in your head, they will eat you alive.
speaker: Hilary Gridley
context: Lenny asks Hilary about helping team members learn to take a punch and deal with hardship. Hilary explains that product leadership is particularly challenging because you're constantly making decisions without clear right answers while everyone looks to you for clarity. This advice came from her former boss when she started reporting directly to a CEO during a pivotal career moment.
text_ko: 프로덕트 리더십(product leadership)은 머릿속의 목소리들을 통제하지 못하면 그게 자신을 완전히 갉아먹어 버리는 자리예요.
text_zh: 做产品负责人这个岗位就是这样，如果你搞不定脑子里那些声音，它们会把你逼疯的。
text_es: El liderazgo de producto es el tipo de puesto donde si no tienes control sobre tus pensamientos y dudas internas, te van a destrozar por completo.

text: I try to focus them less around how you litigate another person's impression of you and more on what is the action that you can take to counter program the narrative that you are afraid that this other person has of you. What are you going to do next to demonstrate that you are the person that you know yourself to be?
speaker: Hilary Gridley
context: Lenny discusses Hilary's specific tactics for teaching team members to deal with hardship. When team members come to her upset about something that happened at work, Hilary teaches them to focus on taking action rather than trying to argue or explain away what happened. She calls this technique 'taking a punch' - learning how to recover from setbacks or criticism.
text_ko: 저는 사람들이 다른 사람이 자신을 어떻게 보는지에 대해 다투는 데 덜 신경 쓰게 하고, 대신 상대가 자신에 대해 갖고 있을 것 같아 두려운 그 서사를 바꾸기 위해 어떤 행동을 취할 수 있을지에 더 초점을 맞추게 해요(counter-program the narrative). 다음에 당신은 스스로 아는 그 사람이라는 걸 보여주기 위해 무엇을 할 건가요?
text_zh: 我试着让他们少纠结于怎么去跟别人争辩你给人的印象，而是更多地想想，你能采取什么实际行动来扭转你担心别人对你的那种看法。接下来你打算做什么来证明，你就是你自己心里清楚的那个人？
text_es: Trato de enfocarlos menos en cómo vas a pelear contra lo que otra persona piensa de ti y más en qué acciones concretas puedes tomar para cambiar esa narrativa que te da miedo que tengan de ti. ¿Qué vas a hacer ahora para demostrar que eres la persona que sabes que realmente eres?

text: I would really love it if more people were like, 'Screw it. I'm going to do something that's probably going to fail. It's important and it's worth doing and I'm going to do it well.'
speaker: Hilary Gridley
context: Lenny asks about the importance of helping people learn to take on hard challenges. Hilary explains that in today's uncertain environment with AI disruption and layoffs, people are gravitating toward safe choices they're likely to succeed at. She wishes more people would embrace difficult, important problems even if they might fail.
text_ko: 더 많은 사람들이 '에라 모르겠다. 아마 실패할지도 모르지만 해볼 거야. 중요한 일이니까 해볼 가치가 있고, 제대로 해낼 거야.'라고 했으면 정말 좋겠어요.
text_zh: 我特别希望更多人能有这种想法："管它呢，我就要去做一件可能会失败的事。这事儿很重要，值得去做，而且我要把它做好。"
text_es: Me encantaría que más gente dijera, 'Al carajo. Voy a hacer algo que probablemente va a fallar. Es importante, vale la pena hacerlo, y lo voy a hacer bien.'

text: People think that the game is all about influencing the CEO, influencing the people around them. You come up thinking like you're the protagonist. But in the story of work, you are probably not the protagonist. You're not special.
speaker: Hilary Gridley
context: Lenny asks about when your leader tells you to do something you disagree with. Hilary shares advice she received from a former Coinbase CPO about reporting to CEOs. Many people mistakenly think their job is to convince the CEO of their vision, but actually the job is to understand the CEO's vision and operationalize it effectively.
text_ko: 사람들은 이 게임이 CEO(최고경영자)나 주변 사람들에게 영향력을 미치는 것이라고 생각해요. 자신이 주인공(protagonist)인 줄 알고 행동하게 돼요. 그런데 일이라는 이야기에서는 아마 당신이 주인공이 아닐 거예요. 특별하진 않아요.
text_zh: 很多人以为职场就是要搞定CEO，搞定他身边的那些人。刚进公司就觉得自己是主角。但是在职场这出戏里，你很可能不是主角。你没那么特别。
text_es: La gente piensa que todo el juego se trata de influir en el CEO, de influir en la gente que lo rodea. Llegas pensando que eres el protagonista. Pero en la historia del trabajo, probablemente no eres el protagonista. No eres especial.

text: I think there's so much cool stuff we're doing right now. And if you are really in it just for pure love of the game, you just love product management, why are you building products for people exactly like you who have all your exact same at a company that sells to other companies that doesn't worry about pricing? I wish that the people who have this pure love of product management would see more of that applied to building for low income people, building for social services, things like that, that really, really need that kind of work.
speaker: Hilary Gridley
context: Lenny mentions Hilary's view that too many PMs are playing on easy mode. Hilary explains her 'hot take' that while she appreciates discussions about craft and taste in product management, she wishes more people with genuine love for building products would tackle harder problems like building for underserved populations rather than just building for people like themselves at well-funded companies.
text_ko: 지금 우리가 하고 있는 일들 중 정말 멋진 것들이 많다고 생각해요. 그리고 만약 진짜로 단순히 제품 관리(product management)를 순수하게 사랑해서 하는 사람이라면, 왜 자기와 똑같은 사람들—같은 배경에 있고 가격 걱정도 별로 하지 않는, 다른 회사에 파는(B2B) 고객들—을 위해서만 제품을 만드는 걸까요? 저는 제품을 진심으로 사랑하는 사람들이 그 열정을 저소득층을 위한 제품 개발이나 사회복지(social services) 같은 분야에 더 썼으면 해요. 그런 곳들이 정말로 그런 노력을 절실히 필요로 하거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们现在做的很多东西都挺酷的。但如果你真的是纯粹热爱这个行业，真的喜欢产品管理(product management)，那你为什么要给和你一模一样的人做产品呢？在一个卖给其他公司、完全不用担心定价的公司里，给那些跟你背景完全相同的人做产品？我特别希望那些真正热爱产品管理的人能把这份热情用到为低收入人群做产品上，为社会服务做产品，做这些真正需要这种专业能力的事情。
text_es: Creo que estamos haciendo un montón de cosas increíbles ahora mismo. Y si de verdad estás en esto por pura pasión, porque te encanta la gestión de productos (product management), ¿por qué construyes productos solo para gente exactamente igual a ti, que tiene exactamente las mismas cosas que tú, en una empresa que le vende a otras empresas y no se preocupa por los precios? Ojalá que la gente que tiene esta pasión genuina por la gestión de productos pudiera enfocarla más en construir para personas de bajos ingresos, para servicios sociales, ese tipo de cosas que realmente, realmente necesitan ese trabajo.

text: When I approach these conversations, I always try to think of them as, even if I don't agree with the feedback, if I don't agree with the decision, what is the insight that I'm missing? How am I wrong about this? In ways like, what would be true for this other person to be right?
speaker: Hilary Gridley
context: Lenny asks about Hilary's approach to transparency and helping team members understand how leaders think. Hilary explains her method for building mental models of how different people in the organization think. Rather than looking for reasons to disagree with decisions, she tries to understand what would need to be true for the other person to be right.
vocabulary_highlights: what would be true for this other person to be right
text_ko: 이런 대화를 할 때 저는 항상, 설령 피드백(feedback)에 동의하지 않거나 결정에 동의하지 않더라도 제가 놓치고 있는 인사이트(insight)가 뭔지 생각하려고 해요. 제가 어디서 잘못 생각하고 있는 걸까? 다른 사람이 옳으려면 어떤 게 사실이어야 할까? 이런 식으로요.
text_zh: 每次遇到这种对话，我都会这样想：就算我不认同这个反馈，不赞成这个决定，但我是不是漏掉了什么关键信息？我哪里想错了？换个角度，要怎样的情况下，对方说的才是对的？
text_es: Cuando me meto en estas conversaciones, siempre trato de pensar: aunque no esté de acuerdo con el feedback, aunque no me guste la decisión, ¿qué se me está escapando? ¿En qué me estoy equivocando? O sea, ¿qué tendría que ser cierto para que esta otra persona tenga razón?
